title.narrative: Sustainable Sanitation through Organic Integrated Livelihoods

description.narrative:
In 2011, SOIL embarked on a pilot project in Cap-Haitien to design and test a social business model for providing sanitation in Haiti’s urban slums. In SOIL’s simple system, wastes from SOIL’s “EkoLakay” toilets are collected and transported to a composting waste treatment facility where they are safely transformed into rich, agricultural-grade compost. Revenue from monthly toilet user fees, waste treatment fees, and compost sales is collected to support ongoing project costs and to showcase the private sector potential to affordably and sustainably provide sanitation services in the world’s most impoverished communities. In February 2014, support from the American Red Cross Community Investment Fund helped SOIL scale up this effort in Cap-Haitien and make improvements to the toilet service and waste treatment operation.
With the support of the American Red Cross, SOIL now plans to pilot the model currently in use in Cap-Haitien in the Port-au-Prince neighborhood of Ti Plas Kazo of Delmas. This proposed project for the American Red Cross is designed to be completed over a 2-year period in two phases. During the first 12-month Phase I SOIL will take the necessary first steps to test this business model in the capital and set the course for a larger social business incubation effort to take place over the subsequent year. SOIL will then submit an updated budget and proposal for a Phase II effort to expand the EkoLakay service to a scale where the social business model can be robustly tested. Ultimately SOIL believes that this project has the potential to demonstrate how the private sector can affordably and sustainably provide sanitation services even in the world’s most impoverished and water-scarce communities. This could have a critical impact on the effort to increase national access to sanitation in Haiti and will hopefully inspire a global shift towards a more ecological and equitable sanitation solution.
